Lecture 01.04: Subspace and Product Topology

Subspace and Product Topology

ğŸ“– Tá»•ng quan

Trong toÃ¡n há»c, má»™t pattern máº¡nh máº½ lÃ : xÃ¢y dá»±ng objects phá»©c táº¡p tá»« objects Ä‘Æ¡n giáº£n. Topology khÃ´ng ngoáº¡i lá»‡!

Hai constructions quan trá»ng nháº¥t:

  1. Subspace topology: Láº¥y má»™t â€œpieceâ€ cá»§a space
  2. Product topology: â€œNhÃ¢nâ€ hai spaces láº¡i vá»›i nhau

VÃ­ dá»¥ trá»±c quan: Subspace topology appears when circle SÂ¹ sits naturally inside plane â„Â² inheriting topology. Product constructions build complexity: plane â„Â² emerges as â„ Ã— â„ (line times line), torus TÂ² as SÂ¹ Ã— SÂ¹ (circle times circle), cylinder as SÂ¹ Ã— [0,1] (circle times interval).

These constructions khÃ´ng pháº£i mere â€œtechnical definitionsâ€â€”theyâ€™re deeply natural vÃ  pervade mathematics. Surfaces embedded trong â„Â³ carry subspace topology making them topological spaces. Spacetime trong relativity is â„ Ã— â„Â³ (time dimension times 3D space). Configuration spaces trong physics and robotics are product spaces tracking multiple parameters simultaneously. Function spaces reveal themselves as infinite products, enabling functional analysis.

Trong bÃ i nÃ y we systematically develop two fundamental constructions. Subspace topology defines induced topology on subsetsâ€”most natural way to make subset inherit topological structure. Product topology on X Ã— Y emerges as weakest topology making projections continuous. Basis for product consists of â€œopen rectanglesâ€ U Ã— V, providing intuitive geometric picture. Projections Ï€â‚, Ï€â‚‚ satisfy beautiful universal property characterizing product categorically. Infinite products âˆáµ¢Xáµ¢ extend construction, vá»›i Tychonoffâ€™s theorem as crown jewel. Box topology appears as alternative (stronger, but pathologicalâ€”not standard).

Táº¡i sao absolutely fundamental? Má»i smooth manifold is locally homeomorphic to products (â„â¿), making product topology essential for differential geometry. Many surfaces emerge as quotients of products (torus from square, Klein bottle from rectangle). Tychonoffâ€™s Theoremâ€”arbitrary product cá»§a compact spaces is compactâ€”is one of most important results trong topology, equivalent to Axiom of Choice! Universal properties provide category-theoretic perspective revealing deeper structure, connecting topology vá»›i abstract algebra and functional analysis.

CÃ¢u chuyá»‡n vá» Inheritance

VÃ­ dá»¥: [0,1] âŠ‚ â„

Trong â„, (0, 0.5) lÃ  open. Trong [0,1], ta muá»‘n (0, 0.5) váº«n â€œopenâ€.
NhÆ°ng (0, 0.5) khÃ´ng pháº£i khoáº£ng má»Ÿ trong â„ (chá»‰ lÃ  má»™t pháº§n).

CÃ¢u chuyá»‡n vá» Coordinates

VÃ­ dá»¥: Open rectangle (a,b) Ã— (c,d) trong â„Â²

  • Projection lÃªn x-axis: (a,b) â€” open trong â„
  • Projection lÃªn y-axis: (c,d) â€” open trong â„
  • Product: (a,b) Ã— (c,d) â€” open trong â„Â²

NguyÃªn táº¯c: Product topology lÃ  smallest topology lÃ m cho projections continuous!

1. Subspace Topology

Äá»‹nh nghÄ©a (Subspace Topology):
Cho (X, ğœ) topological space vÃ  A âŠ† X. Subspace topology trÃªn A lÃ :

\[\tau_A = \{U \cap A : U \in \tau\}\]

NÃ³i báº±ng lá»i: Open sets trong A = intersections cá»§a open sets trong X vá»›i A.

KÃ½ hiá»‡u: (A, ğœ_A) gá»i lÃ  subspace cá»§a X.

VÃ­ dá»¥ 1: Interval trong â„

A = [0, 2] âŠ‚ â„ (Euclidean topology)

Open sets trong A:

  • [0, 1) = (âˆ’1, 1) âˆ© [0,2]
  • (1, 2] = (1, 3) âˆ© [0,2]
  • (0.5, 1.5) = (0.5, 1.5) âˆ© [0,2]
  • [0, 2] = â„ âˆ© [0,2]
  • âˆ… = âˆ… âˆ© [0,2]

ChÃº Ã½: [0, 1) open trong [0,2] nhÆ°ng khÃ´ng open trong â„!

VÃ­ dá»¥ 2: Circle trong â„Â²

SÂ¹ = {(x,y) : xÂ² + yÂ² = 1} âŠ‚ â„Â²

â€œOpen arcâ€ trong SÂ¹ = intersection cá»§a open disk vá»›i SÂ¹.

Äá»‹nh lÃ½ (Subspace is Topology):
ğœ_A thá»a mÃ£n ba topology axioms.

Chá»©ng minh:

(T1): âˆ… = âˆ… âˆ© A âˆˆ ğœ_A, A = X âˆ© A âˆˆ ğœ_A âœ“

(T2) Unions:
{UÎ± âˆ© A} vá»›i UÎ± âˆˆ ğœ.
â‹ƒ(UÎ± âˆ© A) = (â‹ƒUÎ±) âˆ© A âˆˆ ğœ_A âœ“

(T3) Finite intersections:
(Uâ‚ âˆ© A) âˆ© (Uâ‚‚ âˆ© A) = (Uâ‚ âˆ© Uâ‚‚) âˆ© A âˆˆ ğœ_A âœ“

Äá»‹nh lÃ½ (Inclusion Continuous):
Inclusion map i: A â†’ X, i(a) = a always continuous.

Chá»©ng minh:
Cho U âˆˆ ğœ. iâ»Â¹(U) = U âˆ© A âˆˆ ğœ_A (by definition!) âœ“

2. Basis for Subspace

Äá»‹nh lÃ½:
Náº¿u â„¬ lÃ  basis cho ğœ trÃªn X, thÃ¬:

\[\mathcal{B}_A = \{B \cap A : B \in \mathcal{B}\}\]

lÃ  basis cho ğœ_A trÃªn A.

á»¨ng dá»¥ng: Äá»ƒ mÃ´ táº£ subspace topology, chá»‰ cáº§n basis cá»§a ambient space!

VÃ­ dá»¥:
Basis cho â„: {(a,b)}
Basis cho [0,1]: {(a,b) âˆ© [0,1]} = cÃ¡c khoáº£ng má»Ÿ trong [0,1]

3. Properties of Subspaces

Äá»‹nh lÃ½ (Relative Closure):
Cho A âŠ† X, B âŠ† A. Closure cá»§a B trong A:

\[\text{cl}_A(B) = \text{cl}_X(B) \cap A\]

Chá»©ng minh: Exercise (sá»­ dá»¥ng definition cá»§a closure).

Äá»‹nh lÃ½ (Subspace cá»§a Subspace):
Náº¿u A âŠ† B âŠ† X, thÃ¬ subspace topology trÃªn A tá»« B báº±ng subspace topology trÃªn A tá»« X.

Trá»±c giÃ¡c: KhÃ´ng quan trá»ng â€œintermediate spaceâ€â€”chá»‰ quan trá»ng ambient space.

4. Product Topology (Finite)

Äá»‹nh nghÄ©a (Product Topology - 2 spaces):
Cho (X, ğœ_X) vÃ  (Y, ğœ_Y). TrÃªn X Ã— Y, product topology lÃ  topology sinh bá»Ÿi basis:

\[\mathcal{B} = \{U \times V : U \in \tau_X, V \in \tau_Y\}\]

NÃ³i báº±ng lá»i: Basis elements = â€œopen rectanglesâ€ U Ã— V.

KÃ½ hiá»‡u: (X Ã— Y, ğœ_XÃ—Y) gá»i lÃ  product space.

VÃ­ dá»¥ 1: â„ Ã— â„ = â„Â²

Basis: {(a,b) Ã— (c,d)} = open rectangles

Open sets: arbitrary unions cá»§a rectangles (má»i open set trong â„Â²!)

VÃ­ dá»¥ 2: SÂ¹ Ã— [0,1] = Cylinder

Basis: {open arc Ã— open interval}


Cylinder = SÂ¹ Ã— [0,1] - Nguá»“n: Wikimedia Commons

VÃ­ dá»¥ 3: SÂ¹ Ã— SÂ¹ = Torus

Basis: {open arcâ‚ Ã— open arcâ‚‚}


Torus = SÂ¹ Ã— SÂ¹ - Nguá»“n: Wikimedia Commons

Äá»‹nh lÃ½ (Product is Topology):
ğœ_XÃ—Y thá»a mÃ£n topology axioms.

Chá»©ng minh:
â„¬ = {U Ã— V} thá»a mÃ£n basis criterion:

  • (B1): X Ã— Y = X Ã— Y âˆˆ â„¬ âœ“
  • (B2): (Uâ‚ Ã— Vâ‚) âˆ© (Uâ‚‚ Ã— Vâ‚‚) = (Uâ‚ âˆ© Uâ‚‚) Ã— (Vâ‚ âˆ© Vâ‚‚) âˆˆ â„¬ âœ“

5. Projections

Äá»‹nh nghÄ©a (Projection Maps):

\(\pi_X: X \times Y \to X, \quad \pi_X(x,y) = x\) \(\pi_Y: X \times Y \to Y, \quad \pi_Y(x,y) = y\)

Äá»‹nh lÃ½ (Projections Continuous):
Ï€_X vÃ  Ï€_Y luÃ´n continuous trong product topology.

Chá»©ng minh:
Cho U âˆˆ ğœ_X open.
Ï€_Xâ»Â¹(U) = U Ã— Y = U Ã— Y (basis element!) âˆˆ ğœ_XÃ—Y âœ“

Universal Property (Characterization):
Product topology lÃ  coarsest topology trÃªn X Ã— Y lÃ m cho Ï€_X, Ï€_Y continuous.

NÃ³i báº±ng lá»i: ÄÃ¢y lÃ  topology nhá» nháº¥t vá»›i projections continuous.

Äá»‹nh lÃ½ (Product Continuity):
f: Z â†’ X Ã— Y continuous âŸº Ï€_X âˆ˜ f vÃ  Ï€_Y âˆ˜ f continuous.

Chá»©ng minh (â‡):
Äá»§ check trÃªn basis. Cho U Ã— V basis element.
fâ»Â¹(U Ã— V) = fâ»Â¹(Ï€_Xâ»Â¹(U) âˆ© Ï€_Yâ»Â¹(V))
= (Ï€_X âˆ˜ f)â»Â¹(U) âˆ© (Ï€_Y âˆ˜ f)â»Â¹(V) âˆˆ ğœ_Z âœ“

á»¨ng dá»¥ng: Äá»ƒ check f: Z â†’ X Ã— Y continuous, chá»‰ cáº§n check coordinates!

6. Finite Products

Äá»‹nh lÃ½ (Associativity):
(X Ã— Y) Ã— Z â‰… X Ã— (Y Ã— Z) â‰… X Ã— Y Ã— Z

Trá»±c giÃ¡c: Products â€œassociateâ€ naturally.

Äá»‹nh nghÄ©a (n-fold Product):
\(X_1 \times X_2 \times \cdots \times X_n\)

Basis: $B_1 \times B_2 \times \cdots \times B_n$ vá»›i $B_i$ basis element trong $X_i$.

VÃ­ dá»¥: â„â¿ = â„ Ã— â„ Ã— Â·Â·Â· Ã— â„ (n láº§n)

Basis: Open rectangles (aâ‚,bâ‚) Ã— Â·Â·Â· Ã— (aâ‚™,bâ‚™)

7. Infinite Products

Váº¥n Ä‘á»: LÃ m sao Ä‘á»‹nh nghÄ©a âˆáµ¢âˆˆI Xáµ¢ vá»›i I infinite?

Attempt 1 (NaÃ¯ve - Box Topology):
Basis = {âˆáµ¢ Uáµ¢ : Uáµ¢ open trong Xáµ¢}

Váº¥n Ä‘á»: Projections khÃ´ng continuous náº¿u I infinite! Box topology â€œtoo fineâ€.

Solution (Product Topology):
Basis = {âˆáµ¢ Uáµ¢ : Uáµ¢ open, Uáµ¢ = Xáµ¢ trá»« há»¯u háº¡n indices}

NÃ³i báº±ng lá»i: Chá»‰ â€œfinitely many coordinatesâ€ non-trivial.

Äá»‹nh nghÄ©a (Infinite Product Topology):

\[\mathcal{B} = \left\{\prod_{i \in I} U_i : U_i \in \tau_i, U_i = X_i \text{ for all but finitely many } i\right\}\]

VÃ­ dá»¥:
â„^âˆ = â„ Ã— â„ Ã— â„ Ã— Â·Â·Â·

Basis element: (aâ‚,bâ‚) Ã— Â·Â·Â· Ã— (aâ‚™,bâ‚™) Ã— â„ Ã— â„ Ã— Â·Â·Â·

Äá»‹nh lÃ½ (Projections Continuous):
Má»i projection Ï€áµ¢: âˆâ±¼Xâ±¼ â†’ Xáµ¢ continuous trong product topology.

Universal Property:
Product topology lÃ  coarsest lÃ m cho all projections continuous.

8. Tychonoffâ€™s Theorem

Äá»‹nh lÃ½ Tychonoff (Tychonoffâ€™s Theorem):

TÃ­ch tÃ¹y Ã½ cÃ¡c khÃ´ng gian compact lÃ  compact (trong product topology).

\[\forall i \in I: X_i \text{ compact} \implies \prod_{i \in I} X_i \text{ compact}\]

ÄÃ¢y lÃ  má»™t trong nhá»¯ng Ä‘á»‹nh lÃ½ quan trá»ng nháº¥t trong topology!

Ã nghÄ©a:

  • Compactness báº£o toÃ n qua products (ngay cáº£ infinite!)
  • Chá»©ng minh cáº§n Axiom of Choice
  • Thá»±c táº¿, Tychonoff âŸº AC (tÆ°Æ¡ng Ä‘Æ°Æ¡ng!)

VÃ­ dá»¥:
[0,1] compact â†’ [0,1]^â„• = {sequences in [0,1]} compact.

á»¨ng dá»¥ng:

  • Banach-Alaoglu theorem (functional analysis)
  • Compactness cá»§a function spaces
  • Existence proofs trong analysis

Chá»©ng minh:
Requires ultrafilter lemma hoáº·c Alexander subbase theorem. (Advanced!)

ChÃº Ã½ quan trá»ng:
Trong box topology, Tychonoff sai! [0,1]^â„• with box topology not compact.

â†’ Product topology lÃ  â€œrightâ€ choice!

9. Examples vÃ  Non-Examples

Example 1: Hilbert Cube

\[H = [0,1]^\mathbb{N} = \prod_{n=1}^\infty [0,1]\]
  • Compact (Tychonoff!)
  • Metrizable
  • Universal space: má»i separable metric space embeds vÃ o H

Example 2: Cantor Space

\[\mathcal{C} = \{0,1\}^\mathbb{N}\]
  • Totally disconnected
  • Perfect (every point lÃ  limit point)
  • Homeomorphic vá»›i Cantor set trong â„

Example 3: Function Spaces

\[\mathbb{R}^X = \{f: X \to \mathbb{R}\}\]

Product topology = pointwise convergence topology.

fâ‚™ â†’ f âŸº fâ‚™(x) â†’ f(x) vá»›i má»i x (pointwise).

Non-Example: â„^â„• trong Box Topology

Box basis: âˆáµ¢ (aáµ¢, báµ¢) (all coordinates non-trivial)

Projections continuous, but not compact! Tychonoff fails.

ğŸ”— Applications and Connections

Physics - Configuration Spaces

Classical Mechanics: Configuration space cá»§a n particles trong â„Â³ = (â„Â³)â¿ = product space. Topology determines possible motions.

Functional Analysis - Weak Topologies

Banach Spaces: Weak-* topology lÃ  product topology induced tá»« evaluations. Tychonoff â†’ Banach-Alaoglu theorem.

Probability - Product Measures

Infinite Coin Flips: {H,T}^â„• vá»›i product topology. Measure theory: product measure (Kolmogorov extension).

Computer Science - Type Theory

Product Types: A Ã— B trong programming languages. Projections = fst, snd. Product topology analogy trong domain theory.

Real-World Example

ğŸ“ Summary

Trong bÃ i nÃ y, chÃºng ta há»c hai constructions quan trá»ng nháº¥t:

âœ… Subspace Topology: ğœ_A = {U âˆ© A : U âˆˆ ğœ}
âœ… Inclusion Continuous: i: A â†ª X always continuous
âœ… Product Topology (Finite): Basis = {U Ã— V}
âœ… Projections Continuous: Ï€_X, Ï€_Y continuous
âœ… Universal Property: Coarsest topology vá»›i projections continuous
âœ… Infinite Products: Basis elements cÃ³ finitely many non-trivial coordinates
âœ… Tychonoffâ€™s Theorem: âˆ Xáµ¢ compact náº¿u má»—i Xáµ¢ compact

Äiá»ƒm chÃ­nh:

  • Subspace = â€œinheritanceâ€ cá»§a topology
  • Product = â€œcoordinateâ€ structure
  • Product topology â‰  box topology (infinite case!)
  • Tychonoff cáº§n Axiom of Choice
  • Universal properties characterize constructions

á»¨ng dá»¥ng:

  • â„â¿ = product cá»§a n copies cá»§a â„
  • Torus = SÂ¹ Ã— SÂ¹
  • Cylinder = SÂ¹ Ã— [0,1]
  • Function spaces = infinite products
